thread.title: Ray Lewis says he's too big to have killed men in Atlanta
thread.title_full: Ray Lewis says he's too big to have killed men in Atlanta

author: BERNIE AUGUSTINE
title: Ray Lewis says he's too big to have killed men in Atlanta
text:
Wednesday, October 21, 2015, 2:54 PM A A Share this URL 
Another day, another bizarre explanation from Ray Lewis about how he couldn’t have killed two men in 2000. 
Lewis, who promoted his new book “I Feel Like Going On: Life, Game and Glory” on his employer’s flagship program Wednesday, told “SportsCenter” anchors Chris McKendry and Jay Harris that he wouldn’t have mixed it up with the victims because he was so much bigger than them. 
“First of all, they’re 4 or 5 freaking inches shorter than me, right? Why would I fight somebody anyway,” the 6-foot-1 former linebacker said. ESPN Ray Lewis also says that the case against him was based on his skin color. 
Lewis described the scene as “chaos” and “25-to-30 people in an all-out brawl” that night in Atlanta, when a Super Bowl party ended with two men, Jacinth Baker and Richard Lollar, dead. Lewis ultimately pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice, a misdemeanor. 
On Tuesday, TMZ reported that Lewis explained in the book that he was dressed too nicely, in a mink coat, “to start mixing it up looking like that.” 
In his “SportsCenter” spot, Lewis said that he lives with the ramification of that night “every day of my life” and the fallout had “nothing to do with me, but everything to do with my skin color and everything to do with my name.” 
Lewis also said that the arresting officers called him the N-word and that he was convicted on misdemeanor obstruction charges because “I defended myself, stupidly.” 
He added that he didn’t settle two civil suits with the victims’ families out of guilt. 
“Guilt is only when you feel guilty and you say, ‘Listen, I’m gonna slide this to you because I really feel bad’,” he said. “I don’t feel bad about that because I sat there and spoke to both families and I said ‘Listen, what I’m doing, this ain’t about me. This is about because you let somebody confuse my name.’”
